comment: #I think this is new. 11...d6 was played in van der Stemen - Karner Tallin 1987 and 11...hxg5!? between Balashov - Tiviakov St. Petersburg 1993 which continued 12.d6 Nc6 13.dxe7 Qxe7 14.Bxg5 d5 but I didn't fancy ny two N's v 2 B's!
reasoning: The comment accurately explains the mistake made by the player, comparing the move 11...d6 to a similar situation in both historical games and stating that the move was not preferred due to the resulting position favoring White.
moves: 1. d4 e6 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. c4 b6 4. g3 Bb7 5. Bg2 Be7 6. Nc3 O-O 7. Qc2 c5 8. d5 exd5 9. Ng5 h6 10. Nxd5 Bxd5 11. cxd5 Bd6
context: This is a game between Milligan, Bernard (as White) and Beecham, Richard (as Black). Last move played: Black plays Bishop to d6
reformulated: 'The move played by Black, moving the bishop to d6, reminded me of two similar games from the past. In van der Stemen vs. Karner in Tallin 1987, we see 11...d6 transitioning to 12.d6 Nc6 13.dxe7 Qxe7 14.Bxg5 d5. Similarly, in Balashov vs. Tiviakov from St. Petersburg 1993, Black's 11...hxg5!? led to 12.d6 Nc6 13.dxe7 Qxe7 14.Bxg5 d5. However, those sequences are not favorable for Black. It seems to me that the situation is uncomfortable for Black without clear tactical or positional justification. It's risky and doesn't seem to offer a solid plan.'
